He says, “I’m still amazed by the guitar. How can two pieces of wood create such beautiful sounds? Different types of wood make different sounds, and that still fascinates me.”

Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven. At sixteen, he wanted to learn the bass guitar. Instead of saving money for one, he decided to build it himself. He studied how different shapes and types of wood affect sound and how to put them together. Although the bass was the first instrument he built, he and his brothers had been making model boats and planes for a long time. Their father taught them how to use tools, and Jonny had also been fixing instruments for his friends.

Jonny’s bass guitar turned out well, but he didn’t think about making guitars as a career at that time. He was also interested in painting and sculpture. After finishing school, he chose to study architecture at university because it involved design. However, halfway through the course, he dropped out because he felt too different from the others. He realized that guitar-making was a form of sculpture that involved creating sound, and he thought it might be a more practical career than pure art since people actually use the guitars.

Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he worked part-time cleaning windows to earn extra money. He sold his first guitars for just the cost of materials, but as he became known as a skilled guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, almost forty years later, he says he is “still scratching a living.” He can only make about ten guitars a year, which limits his income.

In the early years, Jonny focused on getting his name out there. He attended music festivals on weekends, letting musicians try his guitars and encouraging them to talk about him. He also had to learn how to price his instruments, which was not easy for him.

Jonny believes it is easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. When he started, many people thought only American-made acoustic guitars were good. UK-made guitars were not seen as valuable, even though there have always been good instrument-making courses in the UK. Now, however, the quality of handmade guitars from the UK is recognized.

Jonny thinks that valuable skills can be learned in classes, and he encourages new instrument-makers to take these courses. However, he also believes that learning through experience is important. He says, “You should look at other instruments, see what works and what doesn’t, and try different things. If you make the back too thin or too thick, the sound won’t be good. If you learn from someone else, you might only learn one method, but if you teach yourself, you learn everything.”

Any discussion about English conversation usually starts with the weather. Following this tradition, I will mention the famous saying by the 18th-century writer Dr. Johnson: "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This saying is still true today, just as it was over two hundred years ago. However, many people who write about this topic either stop here or try to explain why the English are so interested in the weather, but they often fail. They make a mistake by thinking that when English people talk about the weather, they are genuinely interested in it.

For example, the American writer Bill Bryson points out that English weather is not very exciting. He says that in England, we do not have extreme weather events like tornadoes or monsoons, which are common in other places. Therefore, he finds it strange that the English are so focused on the weather. On the other hand, the English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman disagrees with Bryson. He believes that English weather is interesting because it is unpredictable. He says that while we may not have tropical storms, living on the edge of an ocean means we can never be completely sure about the weather.

I believe that both Bryson and Paxman are missing the main point. Our conversations about the weather are not really about the weather itself. Instead, talking about the weather is a way for English people to connect with each other. For example, when someone says, "Nice day, isn’t it?" or "Ooh, isn’t it cold?" they are not really asking for information about the weather. These phrases are just polite greetings or ways to start a conversation.

In fact, talking about the weather serves a social purpose, similar to how monkeys groom each other to bond. There are specific situations where weather talk is used. Some people think that English people talk about the weather all the time, but that is not true. There are three main situations for weather talk: as a simple greeting, as a way to start a conversation, or as a fallback topic when there is an awkward silence. 

This means that while it may seem like English people talk about the weather a lot, it is often just a way to keep the conversation going. An English conversation might start with a weather greeting, move to more weather talk to break the ice, and then return to weather talk when the conversation slows down. This is why people from other countries, and even some English writers, think that the English are obsessed with the weather.

Alice Leader was standing in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain, explaining to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds how amazing it was that the Romans built a wall that is 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were excited about this trip, choosing it over more popular destinations like Spain, Greece, or France. However, they wanted to know why the wall was built, and Alice felt she didn’t have good answers. Unable to find a historical novel that would help her explain life at the Wall during Roman times, she decided to write one herself.

After teaching for 31 years, Alice started her new career as an author in 2001. She felt nervous but excited about this big change. “Teaching is like acting; it’s a performance every day and very demanding. Writing is thrilling and less tiring. My former colleagues envy me because I still connect with children through my stories,” she said. Alice wants her novels to fill a gap in children’s fiction. “Many young adult books today focus on negative experiences. They are well-written but often dark, or they are complete fantasy, like Harry Potter. My books are different.”

Alice always taught English and History together, using stories like the Tale of Troy to make lessons more interesting. She loves the moment when a child goes from being bored to being interested. “I enjoy having bored children because it challenges me to engage them,” she explained. She sees her writing as a continuation of her teaching. 

The idea to write her first novel came when she realized she would soon have an empty nest as her two sons were leaving home. Her head teacher suggested she take a creative writing course, which surprised her. “I had been teaching for 25 years, and I didn’t want to spend my summer on a course I thought I didn’t need.” Before joining the course, she had to submit a piece of her writing, which she only learned about a few days before it started. “I quickly wrote a story about a Roman couple and their baby-to-be.” After three hours and 30 pages, she sent it in and was accepted.

During the course, her classmates reviewed her work and encouraged her to publish it. With only 8,000 report cards as proof of her writing skills, she asked her head teacher for a year off to write her first novel. Alice’s husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor, and his help was crucial in editing her book. “My mother-in-law thinks we are rival authors, but I believe we work well together. He improves what I write, changing sentences and suggesting better words, while I tend to add more scenes. That’s the difference between a fiction writer and an editor.”

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to compete in a special race. This race would have Jonny racing in a car on the roads, while Alistair would race on a mountain bike across the countryside. The race took place in the beautiful and hilly Yorkshire Dales in northern England. 

As they prepared to start, Jonny expressed his excitement, saying, “I’ve never done anything like this before! These roads have beautiful views, and it’s very cold, so I’ll be warm in the car.” Alistair, dressed in warm cycling clothes, was also eager. He joked about Jonny’s driving skills, saying, “I might just stop for a cup of tea halfway up.”

The race began at Semerwater lake and would finish at Fleet Moss, Yorkshire’s highest road, which is about 350 meters high. While the car could handle the distance easily, Alistair faced a tough start with a steep hill. They quickly shook hands and started the race. Alistair sped off on his bike, while Jonny got into his car and drove away. The big question was who would reach the finish line first.

Jonny’s confidence quickly faded when he encountered a giant tractor blocking the road just 15 seconds into his drive. He complained to the cameraman, “If Alistair beats me, it’s all down to this farmer!” After getting past the tractor, Jonny continued driving, while Alistair struggled with the steep hill. He had to get off his bike and carry it up the slope, passing walls and fences, while sheep watched him curiously.

Finally, Alistair reached the top of the hill. With the sun shining and open land ahead, he started to pick up speed. Meanwhile, Jonny faced more challenges on the narrow roads of the local villages. He had to slow down to get through a very tight corner and a stream on the road. Once he was clear of the last village, he raced straight towards the finish line.

Neither brother knew how close they were to each other. As Jonny sped down the final stretch to Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road. He pushed hard, and just as he reached the finish line, he slammed on the brakes. Looking up, he asked the crowd, “Is he here?” When they said no, he raised his arms in celebration, shouting, “Yes!”

A few moments later, Jonny arrived in his car and stepped out. “Well done,” he said to Alistair, feeling disappointed. “I’m gutted.”

The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass, toss it up to serve, and hit it, hearing only the echo of your own shots. The well-kept grass, the rich history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all create a peaceful atmosphere that helps you focus. This silence is good for my game. The hardest part of a tennis match for me is to block out everything except the game and the point I’m playing. When a point ends, the silence is broken by applause, cheers, and people shouting my name. I hear them, but it feels distant. I don’t think about the fifteen thousand people watching me closely or the millions watching around the world as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life.

I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, who has been my coach since I was young, taught me that this is the most important tournament. By the time I was 14, I was sharing my dream with friends that I would play there one day and win. Before 2008, I had played and lost to Federer twice in the finals. The loss in 2006 was not too hard for me; I was just happy to have made it that far. Federer won easily, but I didn’t mind much. However, losing in 2007 was very painful. I knew I could have played better, and it was my mind that let me down. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room after that match. Losing is always hard, but it hurts more when you have a chance to win and you lose it.

Toni, who is usually very tough on me, surprised me by saying there was no reason to cry and that there would be more chances at Wimbledon. I told him he didn’t understand; I felt this was my last chance to win. I know how short a professional athlete's career can be, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment is important, but some moments are more important than others, and I had let a big one slip away in 2007. There was nothing Toni could do to make me feel better. But he was right in the end. Another chance came in 2008, just one year later. I felt confident that I had learned from my previous loss and that this time my mind would be strong. 

The best sign that I was ready was my belief that I would win. The night before the final, at dinner with family, friends, and my team, we didn’t talk about the match. I didn’t tell them not to mention it, but they understood that I was already focused on the game in my mind. From that moment until the match started, that space in my head was mine alone.

In early April 1957, a young and idealistic Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa. In her first letter home, she wrote, "I am living in the Africa I have always longed for." She would spend most of her life in Africa, working as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. 

In 1963, Jane became famous when Britain’s National Geographical Society published articles and made documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including popular children's books and the bestselling book "In the Shadow of Man," which has been translated into 47 languages and is still available today. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes overshadows her real achievements.

Many articles and interviews tell her life story, but they often focus on her as a young girl seeking adventure or as a privileged woman who wanted to live with wild animals. These images do not fully represent her important work. Jane Goodall should be recognized as a leading zoologist and a pioneer in her field because of her extensive research and the influence of her students in biological sciences. 

She changed our understanding of chimpanzees, showing that they have social and emotional lives similar to humans. Before her work, people did not know that chimpanzees ate meat or used tools. She discovered that chimpanzees have emotions like ours and that they have unique cultural traditions in their communities across Africa. Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe," published in 1986, is considered the most important work on chimpanzee research.

Jane Goodall's long-term study of wild chimpanzees in Gombe State, Nigeria, is regarded as one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world. She changed how we study animals and how we view ourselves as humans. 

Even as a child, Jane showed signs of her future as a biologist. In the autumn of 1939, when she was just five years old, she disappeared one day. The police and her family searched for her. After a long search, she returned, covered in straw. When her mother asked where she had been, Jane explained that she wanted to know how hens lay eggs. To find out, she had hidden in a henhouse for five hours until a hen laid an egg. This curious nature was an early sign of her future career in biology.

During our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using the voice of a playful 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to viewers of children’s TV shows and cartoons, as well as people who have seen computer programs about health and safety. “I just did a voiceover about back injuries,” she says, “so I had to learn how to say many medical terms quickly.” 

Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. “Many actors, even famous ones, think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,” she says. “But there is more to it. You have to bring the script to life for an audience that can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many well-known people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions because of their fame, but often they don’t get the roles because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.”

After school, Shirley joined a drama course, hoping for a traditional acting career. During the course, she occasionally worked singing jingles for TV ads. “One day,” she says, “the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the voice of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and surprisingly got a major role.” Shirley discovered she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. “Things just happened for me,” she says. “In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character, her brother, and her mother.”

Adult female actors often provide the voices for young boys and girls because their voices are lighter than those of male actors. Hiring child performers involves complicated procedures and many forms, which production companies prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create different sounds and collects new voices by watching children’s TV. 

Cartoons are the best part of her job, which also includes educational videos and vacuum cleaner ads. “Those are tough because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my experience helps,” she says. “I’ve learned that the trick is to smile while you talk – it makes your voice sound bright and cheerful. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; interacting with other actors makes a big difference.”

The competition for voiceover work is strong, and having a good showreel – a recording that shows what the artist can do – is very important. “It’s worth investing in a strong showreel,” Shirley says. “There are agencies that help voiceover artists create them.” She believes she has reached the top of her profession through hard work as much as talent. “Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.”

For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley suggests attending “specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.” She also believes a love for human sound is essential, describing herself as obsessed with voices and becoming the characters she performs. “If I’ve been in the studio doing a specific American voice, for example, it can take over me, and I’ll be speaking like that for hours or even days afterwards,” she says. “My children have grown up hearing their mom talk in completely different voices.”

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This is understandable because cartooning is a job many children dream about, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually give up these childhood dreams and choose more practical careers, like being a tax lawyer or making car parts. The idea that you can earn a living by drawing simple pictures, like those in high school notebooks, seems silly at first. But some people do make a living this way.

Not everyone becomes a cartoonist in the same way, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I had a typical childhood for a cartoonist. I loved comic strips, contributed to school publications, and was known as "the kid who draws." I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, I showed my illustrations to different companies. I was lucky to find someone at a newspaper who needed political cartoons about local issues. I created some ideas, and they bought them. Soon, I was making enough money to support myself.

You don’t need much to become a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even to be a great artist. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. However, if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as there are teachers. While the technical skills needed to be a cartoonist are low, it is still a challenging job. You should only try to become a cartoonist if you feel you cannot do anything else. It is much easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and allows time for family, home repairs, and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better chance you have of making a living from your art. I have created political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also worked as a writer, caricaturist, and designer. I take on all kinds of work because you can learn a lot, even from jobs you don’t really want to do. It helps to be intelligent, well-read, and curious about the world.

Now, let’s talk about the business side of being a cartoonist. In the past, many cartoonists could find regular jobs with different newspapers and magazines. But those days are fading. Today, cartooning is often an entrepreneurial activity, which means you not only have to create the work but also sell it. The more comfortable you are with selling, the more successful you will be. I have seen many cartoonists with average creativity but strong business skills do much better than those who are very talented but lack other skills.

It surprises me how often I meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried that they won’t even let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ put a circle around it, and write your name and the date next to it. But honestly, it is more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it is not a disaster – it could actually be a lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out my things. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. It was a nice, black guitar made in Japan. I usually hate getting rid of things, so I was surprised that I wanted to throw this guitar away. I took it to the dump and was about to leave it there when a young man approached me, looking confused. He asked, “You’re not going to throw that away, are you?” I told him I was, and I started to feel regret. He asked if he could take it, and I said yes. After that, I felt sad about my decision for a long time.

A few months ago, I received an email that changed everything. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish he was eating. That’s how I felt when I opened the email from a guitar dealer named Keith Rushton. He told me, “I’ve got your electric guitar.” It had been sold many times since the young man took it from me. Keith found my name and address on a label on the guitar. He realized the information was probably old, but he used my name to find me online. He eventually contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was so emotional that I almost cried. I would have paid anything for it, but his price was very fair. I had forgotten that my dad always put name labels on my things, including the guitar. I could imagine my dad laughing at this strange situation.

My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar because it was popular in the 1970s. I loved the sound of it; it was calming and gentle. Unlike the violin, it didn’t sound bad when a beginner played it. But I struggled to improve, so I switched to the electric guitar and played easier songs. This was also the time of punk music, when anyone could be a rock star, even if they weren’t great musicians.

When I opened the box that Keith sent me and took out my old guitar, I suddenly remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again felt amazing; it was smooth and smaller than I remembered. I sat down to play, but then I wanted to stand up and put the strap over my shoulder because that’s how electric guitars are played. My fingers remembered where to go. I couldn’t explain the chords I wanted to play, but my hands just knew what to do. My fingers felt the familiar pain of pressing down the strings to play a chord. 

The electric guitar is not really meant to be played alone. Now that I’m learning it again, I think I should form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or perhaps I can find other people my age who have had similar experiences. We could call ourselves “The Regainers!”

There has been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote my book, Insomniac, about people who cannot sleep, I felt like I was one of the few warning others about the dangers of not getting enough sleep. Lack of sleep affects our minds, bodies, and moods. People who struggle with sleep understand how important it is. It is good that sleep is finally getting the attention it deserves. However, I wonder about dreams. I haven’t heard much about them in these discussions. We often lose our dreams when we wake up early. The last hour or two of sleep we miss is mostly REM sleep, which is when we have the most vivid dreams. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep time in REM. Over a lifetime of 90 years, a person will spend around six or seven years in REM sleep. When researchers prevent people from having REM sleep, they tend to have more REM sleep the next night to make up for it. This suggests that dreams serve a purpose.

When REM sleep was discovered in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who believed that understanding dreams was the best way to understand our minds. However, later research showed that it is not that simple. The focus of dream studies shifted from psychological reasons to physical ones. Currently, there is not much agreement among dream researchers, according to Harvard sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. 

Dreams are important. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than others. He concluded that the use of dreams increases with a person's interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams because films are very dream-like. But I wonder if only creative people benefit from their dreams. Don’t teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively?

Stickgold explains that dreams help us connect ideas in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from our past and present. Dreams may help us discover new patterns and combinations that break our usual ways of thinking. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when woken from other sleep stages. They come up with unexpected ideas that make sense in a unique way. This is what creativity is about, according to Stickgold. 

I find that I write better after having intense dreams. Even a difficult dream, or one I can barely remember, seems to help me think more clearly. On those days, my ideas come out so quickly that I can hardly keep up with typing. I don’t know exactly how it works, but it does seem to help. Creativity is not just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and everyone needs their brains to work well. We all need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why dreaming is important.

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray moved from London to a small coastal town in south-west England. When you enter her studio, you see a beautiful view of the sea and several empty frames on the walls, along with happy photos of her two daughters. Susie is a well-known copyist artist, skilled at recreating famous paintings from the past. She can copy the rich colors of early 20th-century impressionist art and the detailed work of 16th-century Caravaggio. It’s surprising that she doesn’t keep any of her own work. “I don’t have any of my own around,” Susie says. “As soon as I finish them, they go.” 

Susie is in high demand. Over her 30 years as a copyist, she has painted works by many great artists, including Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her copies are so accurate that art experts sometimes mistake them for the originals. While the original paintings can sell for millions, her copies sell for a few hundred to £12,000, depending on how much time she spends on them. Susie doesn’t reveal most of her clients, but they include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors are true art lovers, but others are more interested in status. One famous buyer likes to show off his “Van Gogh” painting, which is actually a copy by Susie. “Many famous people pass off my copies as originals,” she says. “That’s their choice.” Some collectors keep the original in a bank safe and display Susie’s copy instead to save on insurance.

Susie is honest about her work. When she copies a masterpiece, she tries to make it look as real as possible because she believes it’s important to respect the original artist. However, she always signs her name on the back of the canvas. Selling a copy as the real thing is illegal, and even though she knows people who have done that, she has never been tempted. Those who make fake art often get into trouble. Susie admits she isn’t rich and has faced challenges, but her situation is better now, and she doesn’t want to risk her reputation.

Before becoming a copyist, Susie worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden after earning her art degree. She earned very little money during that time, but it helped her develop her skills and love for plants. She learned to be very precise and to get things right on the first try. She has no regrets about that job, but she is happy to have found something more financially rewarding.

When younger artists ask Susie for advice, she emphasizes the importance of learning to draw accurately. She has studied a lot to reach her level of skill. She can draw plants, create perfect copies of 15th-century art, and reproduce 20th-century abstract art, but she now focuses on French impressionists, especially Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. Susie believes many people think modern art is easy, but she explains that impressionists painted quickly and freely while also being very careful, which makes it challenging to replicate.

Given her talent, it seems strange that Susie doesn’t create her own original art. Isn’t art about self-expression? Couldn’t a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She explains that her work is the result of years of training and hard work, and she earns a good living from it. She has tried to create her own art, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they ended up looking like photographs—fine, but not better than that. It’s like living on simple food after enjoying meals from a top chef. Susie is a perfectionist, and that drives her work.

During her racing career, Ellen MacArthur cared most about the sea and being the fastest on it. Since she was a child, sailing had been her great passion. She felt a strong connection with the boats that took her around the world; they worked together as one. When she returned to land, everyday life felt unimportant. People would ask her about the race, but she quickly wanted to be back on the ocean, challenging nature, even in places that had almost defeated her.

After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo round-the-world race, she showed me the small, stuffy cabin of her boat, Kingfisher. This was her home, workplace, and survival space for 94 days. She explained how carefully she planned everything, even counting the exact number of kitchen paper rolls she would need. Preparation was crucial for her. She proudly displayed her unappetizing stock of foil-wrapped, freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and neatly organized medical supplies. Her ability to keep the boat clean was as impressive as her sailing skills. The boat was her entire world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen views the world as a boat: a small, beautiful, and fragile thing with limited resources. A key moment for her was a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey on albatrosses. This experience made her reflect and see things differently. The many abandoned whaling stations served as a warning to her. She felt that humans often take what they want and move on without thinking.

When I visited Ellen's office, she was finishing a heated conference call. She explained why we need to act now to protect the planet. "We are not making more coal, oil, or gas. They are valuable resources we have only once. We need to find ways to use them wisely." Initially, her message was negative—encouraging people to use less—but she later realized there was a more positive approach. Now, she focuses on reusing materials, like reusable industrial carpet tiles.

For the past three years, she has been visiting factories, mines, and power stations, discussing our dependence on non-renewable resources with government and business leaders. "I will never be an expert," she says, "but I love learning. I couldn't ignore the current situation. Compared to sailing, this feels much more important. It’s about finding how my voice can be most helpful."

Ellen also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that helps young people rethink and design a sustainable future through business and education. "I do miss the adventure of being at sea," she admits. "It defines who I am. You feel connected to everything around you, and you don’t have time to feel lonely. You focus on records, practical matters, and survival. My new message is not as simple as saying, 'I want to be the fastest around the world.' I may have been the fastest, but this work is more meaningful than anything I’ve ever done."

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous. He hopes to inspire other young people to explore the outdoors instead of just playing on computers and video games. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves "Team Romero." Climbing Everest is just one part of their goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Very few people achieve this before they turn thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he becomes a teenager.

I spoke to several experienced Everest climbers, and none of them thought it was a good idea to take a 13-year-old up the highest mountain in the world. They agreed that Jordan might be physically strong enough, but they were unsure if he had the emotional strength needed. They also questioned whether he had enough experience to make good decisions while climbing safely.

The Romero family has heard these opinions before. Paul says, "I know there is criticism, but I can’t focus on it – we have a lot to do. We think about the risks, but we believe our experience as climbers will help us. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is getting stronger and more mature." 

I also wonder about Jordan’s reasons for wanting to climb. Is it just his father's ambition? Paul insists, "This project isn’t about me trying to become famous through my son. At first, Jordan thought about doing this later in life, but we decided, ‘Why not now?’ We talk to him often to make sure he still wants to do it."

When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about this challenge, he says, "I just focus on achieving my goal." In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb is seen as a chance to break records. This creates a challenge for Jordan. While some people think that focusing on achievements takes away from the enjoyment of climbing, if Jordan wants to inspire others, he needs to engage with the media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something impressive, like climbing Everest.

Paul adds, "If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will end this project and go to the gym."

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it’s likely they are not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they usually don’t know who he is. I just started studying music, but my classmates know as little about classical music as other teenagers do. If you don’t know who created the music, you probably don’t own any of their recordings. This is sad for classical music fans. Last year, only 3% of concert tickets sold were for classical music, and the average classical album sells only 300 copies. It’s hard to believe.

So, why is interest in classical music declining? Older people often blame our love for TV and video games, but I don’t think that’s the reason. The truth is that classical music doesn’t attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the main buyers of music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who enjoy classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I’m not a big fan of classical music. I like many styles, but my classical music collection is probably close to that 3% figure.

Why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, can be hard for us. We prefer fast talking, playing, and thinking. Experts say we can only pay attention for about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but just right for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while understanding classical music takes time and focus. Also, pop music often talks about issues that matter to teenagers, while classical music usually does not.

The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families would play music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. Now, you can find any music online, but classical music is rarely part of our daily lives. When was the last time you heard classical music in a store? One of my teachers says that more people are attending classical concerts now, but I doubt many of them are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but when I look at the audience, I mostly see older people. I don’t know why middle-aged people like classical concerts more, but I do know that if your parents love something, you might want to avoid it.

Some people say schools are to blame for teenagers’ lack of interest in classical music, but many kids are excited to play classical music in their school orchestras. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy classical music when they perform, but it’s not their favorite music otherwise. The two activities have become separate. When we want to relax, we usually choose pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. “I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here,” she said with a smile. Her mother was getting out of the other side, so she didn’t hear Bonnie, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother already knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among the trees on a hillside; it looked confusing at first. Then she saw signs: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… “Riding centre,” Bonnie said, suddenly interested. “Headmaster’s study,” her mother replied. “This way.” Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between the trees. “I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog,” Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to do so.

A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his study, while Bonnie waited outside the door. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. “Why should I just sit here?” she thought. “I’ll be thrown out soon anyway, so why not get it over with?” She left the building and went to the riding centre, following the sign. There was a nice old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but there was no one there. She approached the horses with respect. They were well cared for, and she could see that right away. Almost every stall was occupied, and she walked along, looking closely at each horse. “I know what you’re doing here,” she said to a small pony, gently touching its nose. 

Then she saw the next horse and stopped. “But aren’t you the best of the lot!” she exclaimed. He was brown with a bit of white. He looked lively, which Bonnie liked. “I feel like we’ve met before,” she said, stroking his neck. Above the stall was his name: Maverick. She suddenly wanted to ride him. “I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle. They can’t be far away.” Bonnie was happy to find that the room with the riding equipment was unlocked. While she was busy putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. 

When she finally sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in control of everything she could see. Her nickname at her old school had been Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. “You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick,” she said with admiration. “I really mean it because I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else.” She nudged him to walk, then to trot. “If I stay here, I think you and I could be great friends,” she said. She rode around the paddock, feeling the rhythm of the movement and the breeze on her face. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he would jump well.

I have met Cody Simpson before, and I have always been impressed by his quiet confidence. The 15-year-old from Australia has already released many successful songs. So, how did a relaxed surfer end up performing in front of thousands of fans? Cody explains, “I first picked up a guitar when I was six and started writing songs at seven.” He remembers that swimming and surfing were more important to him at that time. “I was 13 and in high school when I posted a few videos online,” he says.

These videos changed everything. He started by sharing a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans began to comment online, asking for more videos. Cody, who had recorded more songs at home, was happy to share them. The response was amazing. 

Cody was also a talented swimmer. He trained hard with great coaches and focused on his sport. But then record labels showed interest in him, and he faced a tough choice: stay in Australia and keep swimming or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the chance. “It was very hard for me, especially at such a young age, to choose a career. Can you imagine being 12 or 13 and trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?” He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to America. “It surprised most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid,” he recalls, remembering their shocked faces. “I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to stay that way in this crazy industry.”

So, Cody packed his bags and moved with his family to the other side of the world, giving up one dream to chase another. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and is not directly involved in his career, they support him from behind the scenes. Cody believes it’s important to have a close group of good people around you to stay grounded.

Of course, everyone has moments of doubt. “Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How does my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight years old, traveling the world and doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a normal life,” Cody admits. “I worry about how this affects him, but my family always reassures me that they support me in everything I do.”

Success in any career comes from being willing to say ‘yes’ to your big opportunity, even if it feels scary. “Everything happened so fast and unexpectedly,” Cody says. “Now, I’m visiting countries I never thought I would see and performing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans. It’s something many people dream of and try to achieve. But I know it won’t last forever.”

I jumped out of bed, pulled back a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked down at the river. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbags that were there to stop the buildings from flooding as the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting the sandbags last week. I had worked long hours with most of the adults in town to help. My grandfather didn’t seem to notice my efforts. 

With one hand on the curtain, I looked at the stretch of dark water created by the release pipe from the wood factory in Milltown. There were fragile ice shelves on both sides, and solid ice further down the river. As I took off my pajamas and put on my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I didn’t know him. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky silver chain, which my famous grandfather brought back from South America. Only my grandfather, my mom, and I know about this chain. I also have his diary from that trip, which I keep under my pillow and read before I sleep. I touched the chain again and went to the kitchen.

“Good morning, Rex,” my mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. “You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training. Be careful.” 

“Thanks, Mom.” I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into my tall grandfather as he came out of his room. 

“Can’t you watch where you’re going?” he shouted. “Where are you going?” 

“Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.” It was obvious from my wetsuit, and he had seen me kayak every morning. I tried to ignore his anger, but it was getting harder. 

“What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,” he said. His words hurt, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He walked away and slammed the bathroom door. My mom came over with a sympathetic smile. 

“Don’t mind him. He’s…” 

“...not himself right now,” I finished for her. I wanted to say he had always been like this, but I tried to be kind to him. When I was younger, he was my hero. He showed me photos of himself in National Geographic magazine, and those old photos still hang on his wall with his medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own trophies to look at, and maybe one day, my own picture in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay loyal to him, even though he is grumpy.

My mom smiled. “At least he’s coming out of his room more. Have a good training session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep going, even in this cold weather!” 

I smiled back as I peeled my banana. “It’ll be warmer in South America if I find sponsors for my expedition.” She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I finished my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried to the boathouse.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her into the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was an unframed painting. It was clearly one of Grandpa's works, but it looked different from his usual style and was obviously unfinished. 

"Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." She looked closely at the painting. It showed a river that took up most of the picture; it was not a river she recognized and might not even be real, just a fantasy. The painting was strange and beautiful in a haunting way. The riverbank was barely visible, with just a hint of green that was easy to miss, drawing the eye into the pale water and towards a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people in the painting, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant scene. Still, she found it fascinating, thinking about autumn coming after a long summer.

Mum spoke again. "It has a name." There was something in her voice that showed her excitement, but Jess noticed it was also a bit distant. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others figure them out. Mum turned the painting over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud: "River Boy." The words felt strangely important to her, but she didn't know why. 

Then she noticed something else. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." 

"Exactly. It's strange, isn't it? For him to be so specific. But maybe he will add the boy later since he hasn't finished it yet. I made the mistake of asking him about it."

"Mum! You should have known better."

"I know, but I couldn't help it. It's such an unusual painting, especially with a name. You can guess what he said."

Jess didn't need to guess. She knew Grandpa's response. "He told you it's not the artist's job to explain a painting because each one has its own life and language, just like a poem. We either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without having to explain it to everyone..."

"… every ignoramus," Jess added.

"Right. He said if artists had to explain their work to everyone who asked, they would never get anything done. And he said..."

Mum interrupted, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him."

"Inspire?" Jess asked.

"Yes, someone who motivates an artist." Jess understood the word. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but he usually meant that the muse wasn't helping him that day or that he needed to be nice to the muse because he had a tough part to work on. He never suggested that the muse was her. In fact, she always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a real person. It was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as strong-willed as Grandpa. 

"He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

When I woke up this morning, I didn’t plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I’m not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad’s Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have gone into the carpet and made a big hole. I’m not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn’t wake up thinking, “Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.” It just seemed like a good idea at the moment, as things often do. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but by then it was too late. This happens to me quite often. 

What I was really trying to do was find a way to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It’s very cute! It’s small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and it has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it, like shepherdesses and old-fashioned ladies. Now, I keep my collection of shells and interesting stones there. Gran knew I loved her corner cabinet, and I was so happy when she gave it to me!

The problem is, it is a corner cabinet, which means it has to fit in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it’s the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is for Mum and Dad, the back one is my sister Angela’s, the little one over the garage is my brother Tom’s, and my room is the size of a broom cupboard. Mum says when Angela goes to university, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. When Tom goes to university, I can choose any room. But since Angela is only fifteen, I think I will be stuck in my small room for a long time. 

I don’t really mind; I like my little bedroom. It’s cozy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe is in the other. I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet into the space between the roof and the floor, but it was just a little too tall. Then I thought, if I can’t cut anything off the cabinet, why not cut a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. Dad calls this “lateral thinking.” I thought he would be pleased with me because he always tells us to “think outside the box.” And that’s exactly what I was doing!

The novel "The Borrowers" tells the story of a family of tiny people who live secretly in the walls and floors of a house. They "borrow" things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the book, I knew it would be difficult to meet people's expectations. Fans of the book have strong opinions about how it should be done. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I wanted to avoid criticism from fans.

The author wanted the series to show the story from the Borrowers' point of view, not from the humans'. This made filming more complicated. The most important thing was to get the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on their borrowing missions, we had to be ten times further away than usual. The crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters to capture the Borrowers' perspective, which meant they went through many pairs of jeans!

We only raised the cameras for aerial shots. One big challenge was to create the right shadows when combining the tiny Borrowers with the normal-sized background. We developed a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous director George Lucas called to ask how we did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floor, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was very surreal. When I asked the actors to carry giant items like oversized scissors, they really got into it. I remember the coins being bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift, which often made the crew laugh.

In the story, there is a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, the actors had to go down a tunnel with hoses, and they found it so scary that they didn’t need to act. I also wanted to get the costumes right, which has been a problem in other TV versions. I had the costumes made from heavy canvas so they looked like doll clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to move; she couldn’t sit down during breaks and had to be sewn into her dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal fabric would have looked too smooth. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don’t think they appreciated my attention to detail!

Most of the action away from the Borrowers' home was filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was challenging for them to react to things that weren’t really there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how they should look, and by the end, I had done 2,000 drawings. They weren’t perfect, but they worked. We didn’t have enough budget for special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly; I once filmed a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But in the end, everything came together, and I think the series successfully captured the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, expecting to see journalists, but there are none. I know that soon, things will get crazy. There will be fake smiles, people pretending to be my friends, and requests for free concert tickets from my dad. “Everything will be fine,” I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone in this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to escape my old life of touring and private tutors. While the rest of the band is here for recording, we are staying for good. I wanted to come to this school to meet real kids. I imagined kids with normal parents, like a mom who works in an office or a dad who mows lawns. That would be so cool and normal.

I walk into the school office. “Hi, I need my schedule, please,” I say to the secretary. “Name?” she asks, looking unfriendly. “Desert McGraw.” “Desirée?” she asks, leaning closer. “Desert,” I repeat. The secretary looks confused. “Oh,” she says, typing my last name on her computer. That’s good because not many people recognize my last name since my dad uses a stage name. “What grade?” she asks. “Eleventh.” “One second, it’s printing,” she replies. Then she hands me my schedule. English Literature is my first class. Great! I like English. But I will be late because it’s in Room 214 on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn’t look lost.

When I reach the door, I hear the teacher calling names. “Aurelio Gonzalez.” “Here.” I slip in quietly and sit at the back of the class. The girl next to me smiles and looks at my outfit—just jeans and a T-shirt. “Nice shoes,” she whispers. I look down at my fancy shoes with flowers. Oh no, I shouldn’t have worn these. “Thanks,” I say. The teacher pauses and calls my name, “Desert... McGraw?” “Here,” I reply. The teacher, Ms. Smigla, smiles and talks a lot. She gives us our course outlines and tells us about the books we will read this year. Then she lets us socialize, which is great.

“So why did you move here?” my new friend asks. I have a few options for my answer. Should I say I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or should I say what my dad thinks? He said, “We need a change, Desert, and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.” I think he just wants to relax at the beach. Why else would they choose a studio so close to the sand? “My dad had to relocate,” I tell her. Yes, it’s easier to lie. “What does he do?” she asks. I know everyone will find out eventually, but I want some time to pretend to be normal. “He’s an artist,” I say, playing with my backpack zipper. “Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.” She doesn’t seem to care much. That’s good.

Not only is the average American teenage girl expected to be the president of the Student Council, but she also needs to have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in all these areas. This is what it means to be a teenager in America today. Boys and girls cannot just go to school and be average; being average is not enough anymore. People think that not having big ambitions is a sign of laziness. 

Kristen Loose, a teenager, says, “Adults often forget how much pressure we have. We have a lot of homework, tests, after-school activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to have a social life.” Even though these stresses are normal for teenagers today, negative stereotypes still exist. Many people in the media describe teenagers as lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some of these traits may be true for a few, many believe it is unfair to label all teenagers this way.

Kristen Loose thinks that many people wrongly assume teenagers spend most of their time watching TV or using their phones. She admits she often has her phone nearby, but she uses it for important things, not just for fun. For teenagers, their phones are tools that help them manage their lives. They are expected to have quick access to information and to be reachable at all times, which can make it seem like they are addicted to their phones. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their homework anywhere, and schoolwork now requires their attention all day and night.

Many teenagers start their days around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often finish their activities after midnight. Their days are filled with school, after-school activities, family responsibilities, and homework. They often get less than the recommended nine hours of sleep each night. A survey by the US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of teenagers get enough sleep. Additionally, 28 percent of teens said they fall asleep in school about once a week because they are too tired.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen believes that after all her activities, she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. Olsen does not spend her free time on social media or watching TV; instead, she focuses on volunteering. She says, “People think teenagers only care about themselves, but my favorite part of the week is volunteering. I love helping others and making a positive impact in my school and community.”

In 20 years, the stereotype of teenagers may change, but they will continue to challenge these ideas and make a difference in the world. There will always be new generations of students who are making their mark before they even finish school.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in Bishop, a mountain town in the US, surrounded by wilderness east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In recent years, this group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This project combines science and adventure, which is likely why teenagers want to join. I visited them one weekend in late spring as they prepared to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or piece of metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a bright trail of light.

As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated lunch box to the bottom of the balloon. Inside the box were a camera, an instrument to measure altitude, and a thermometer to check temperature changes during the ascent. They also placed two GPS trackers on the outside of the lunch box to help find it later. A gas tank, donated by a supporter from another state, was used to inflate the balloon, which grew to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour trip to get the gas tank, but he didn’t mind. For these kids, that’s just part of the experience.

Finally, it was time for lift-off. They counted down, “Five, four, three, two, one,” and the balloon started to rise. Some of the teenagers ran after it with flashlights, trying to keep it in sight as it floated into the dark sky. There was a quiet moment filled with wonder before the balloon disappeared.

After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside, looking at the clear sky, which was surprising so close to the busy city of Los Angeles. I saw a boy climb into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. One girl whispered, “We’re the only ones talking.” Another girl replied, “I know.” Suddenly, a meteor shot across the sky.

As the balloon rose, the air pressure decreased, causing it to expand until it popped with a loud bang. A parachute helped the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students planned to find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Retrieving it was not easy, but that was part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in remote areas. The group’s leader said, “Recoveries are a big part of the program.” They had only lost two lunch boxes in 53 launches. He added that this experience helps them learn about the landscape in a way they wouldn’t normally.

On this occasion, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. To reach it, the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box landed on a high peak or in a tall tree. The leader noted that these students are familiar with the Eastern Sierra, so what seems wild to some is just a normal part of life for them.

In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, near a waterfall. Unfortunately, the camera did not capture any shooting stars. While this was disappointing, it gave them a chance to discuss atmospheric waves and how they might behave above mountains. It also became another exciting story to share with anyone who asked.

Chloe Morgan admits that she was not very interested in science, especially Palaeontology, until she was fifteen. Her interest began by chance when her younger brother was excited about dinosaurs, a phase many children go through. Although she had ignored this interest before, she helped him with a science project and found an article about recent discoveries in Palaeontology that amazed her. She realized she wanted to pursue this field.

Chloe recalls meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already well-known despite being young. She felt nervous at first, worried he might think she was just an annoying kid. However, she felt more comfortable when he showed patience and listened to her questions.

When discussing how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows, Chloe expresses her frustration. She acknowledges that films like Jurassic Park have increased public interest in dinosaurs, but they often misrepresent palaeontologists. She feels they are usually portrayed as either strange geniuses or socially awkward people, which does not reflect the reality of their work.

Chloe explains that her job is very diverse. She spends time digging up dinosaur bones, working in laboratories to analyze fossils, and writing scientific articles. Although it is not her main job, she also believes it is important to communicate scientific findings to the public, especially to young people. She wants to inspire them to learn about science and the natural world, starting with dinosaurs.

Chloe was involved in the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs, where she helped ensure the accuracy of how dinosaurs were portrayed. She found it easy to work on the project because there were few mistakes to correct. The documentary attracted viewers of all ages and presented dinosaurs in a way that was more realistic than in movies like Jurassic Park.

Chloe believes that dinosaurs continue to fascinate us because they represent the explorer in all of us. They spark our imagination and the desire for discovery. In a world that feels smaller, dinosaurs remind us that there is still much to learn, and Palaeontology allows us to explore the past.

When you travel by car with your family, even if you are six years old, you probably know that you are not “there yet,” even if you keep asking, “Are we there yet?” The truth is, once you arrive, it’s not “there” anymore; it’s “here.” So if you think you might be “there,” you should really be asking, “Are we here yet?” 

I’m sure no one wants to be “there” more than the parents who hear that question over and over on long trips. Think about it: wouldn’t you rather relax in the back seat, with nothing to do? You could watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while enjoying the beautiful views outside the window. Meanwhile, one of your parents is in the front seat, giving out juice boxes and cookies, changing the radio, and making sure everything goes smoothly.

But then, something can happen that ruins the peace. In my case, it’s usually my younger brother, Tim. He might put his foot on my side of the seat. I can’t let that happen, so I put my foot on his side. Soon, he’s all over my space, and a fight starts. Our parents have to reach back to separate us while driving, telling Tim to stay in his own seat. This calms things down for a bit, and we can enjoy the scenery again.

Later, when I’m trying to read, I feel a draft on my arm. The window isn’t open, so where is it coming from? Tim is next to me, quietly blowing air in my direction. He’s not touching me, so he thinks he’s being clever. This makes me angry, and soon he gets yelled at again, causing more chaos in the car. 

Over the years, Dad has come up with ways to handle us in the back seat. When we ask, “Are we there yet?” he often says, “Yes, we’re here. Get out of the car.” But when we point out that we are still on the highway, he replies, “Oh, then maybe we’re not there yet.” This usually keeps us quiet for a while. 

You can tell when you finally arrive because the adults quickly get out of the car and move away from the kids who have bothered them for hours. So remember: if your parents are still close enough to answer your question, the answer is no, you are not there yet.

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope that customers will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains their motivation: “There is so much technology today. Everyone is busy with their phones and gadgets. We wanted to bring people together in a way that doesn’t involve screens. It’s natural for people to connect and communicate.”

The games played in their café are called ‘Eurogames’. These games often have gentle themes, like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources, keeping everyone engaged until the end. This idea was improved in ‘co-operative’ games, where all players work together to win or lose as a team, which encourages more social interaction. One popular co-operative game is Pandemic, designed by North American Matt Leacock. In Pandemic, players work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings, which is based on the famous book. He remembers feeling scared and excited while playing it with friends, and he wanted to create a game that gave everyone a good experience, whether they won or lost.

Leacock’s love for board games started when he was a child. He enjoyed receiving games as birthday gifts but often felt disappointed when they didn’t meet his expectations. With help from his uncle, he began to redesign games to make them better. Pandemic became very successful, and its follow-up game included a lot of storytelling. Leacock explains that it is similar to video games because players develop characters, learn new rules, and the game’s story changes as they play.

Interestingly, the growth of the video game industry has helped the popularity of modern board games. Many people now play games on their smartphones, making them more open to playing board games too. Ben Hogg, who works for a game company, says, “Everyone plays mobile games now. Most people with smartphones have at least one game they enjoy.” 

For a while, video games allowed some social interaction, like playing together in arcades or on the couch. However, as multiplayer games moved online, players became more distant from each other. This led some people to seek out board games to play with others in person. 

At John and Zuzi's busy café, it is clear that tabletop gaming has become more than just entertainment. In our increasingly online world, games are now a way to connect and share experiences directly with others, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest hits in the UK in recent years. His story shows that endurance and persistence are very important in the music business, even if your career starts with many challenges. He says his mother was an amazing singer who encouraged him to play the guitar. The only radio station he listened to at home was for middle-aged people, which influenced his music taste as he grew up. He was 12 years old when he first heard a modern song. Around the same time, he had to choose between playing tennis, which he did at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the school music room learning songs on the piano. He said, “I was doing well in tennis, but it was not what I wanted to do for my whole life. It was just too much hard work.”

At 17, he left school to pursue a career as a performer. He formed a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but did not share his passion for performing. Jamie remembers telling his parents, “This is what I want to do. I have been writing lyrics in economics class and playing the piano every day while others were outside.” His father gave him 18 months to succeed; if he didn’t, he would need to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he was signed by a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, the record labels wanted him to be a solo artist, so he had to part ways with his friend.

Eventually, he found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album. However, fame and success did not come easily. He said, “I feel like I’ve been in the wrong place at the wrong time for most of my artist career, but as a writer, I’ve been in the right place at the right time.” Writing for other artists is where he truly found his success. He believes he is one of the main writers in the UK that labels turn to for new artists. He helps launch their careers and sometimes has to explain that aiming for chart success is not something to be ashamed of. He asks them, “Don’t you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?” He believes they should create something amazing that will also sell well.

It is refreshing to hear someone in pop music speak openly about wanting to write big hits. Jamie is not arrogant; he simply knows he wants to write number one songs and has the talent to do it. Instead of worrying about what others think, he focuses on his goals. He says, “When I go into the studio with someone, we need to aim for global success and write the best music for next year. It’s not just about what’s cool; we want to create classic modern pop songs.”

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very popular online, but many people, like me, may not know him because we don’t watch videos of people doing bike stunts. He is known as a ‘street trials cyclist.’ This means he jumps from difficult places, like roofs or walls, to land safely in other tricky spots. He films these stunts and shares them online.

When I interview him, we meet at a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local kids know who he is, and some older people come to greet him, calling him ‘an absolute legend.’ After watching him perform, I agree with them. At first, I was a bit doubtful, but I am impressed by his bravery, creativity, and willingness to take risks. Before each stunt, he explains what he plans to do, and sometimes I can’t believe he will succeed. When I compliment him, he seems uninterested and a bit sad. Even though he is famous online, Tony says he doesn’t like being a celebrity. He finds it hard to connect with fans. He understands the importance of talking to them, but he prefers to focus on doing his stunts.

This is interesting because his fame comes from social media and the small cameras that help create this content. He says, “This technology allows people like me to earn money.” However, he feels that many people are always filming themselves or looking at screens, and he doesn’t fully agree with that.

Tony makes a good living from his videos, which is impressive because, in the past, this would have just been a hobby. After many years of interviewing top athletes, I have learned that two important things help a child become a great competitor: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These qualities can be more important than talent and help someone keep going even after failures. In risky sports, it is especially important to have mental strength.

Even at the park, Tony fell a few times on what he thought were easy but new challenges. He just got back up and kept trying until he succeeded. Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some people think he is reckless and takes too many risks. He responds, “Those who criticize me may care, but they don’t understand. They probably have never tried riding a trials bike and don’t know much about the sport. They don’t realize I get advice from experts to reduce risks.”

Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He explains, “People are different. Some are never scared, and they shouldn’t be doing these sports. It’s important to know the dangers. Others can’t overcome their fear, while some of us can. I feel fear but find a way to move past it. I’m not addicted to risk; I spend a lot of time planning and preparing. Sometimes, I ride around for a while to get ready before trying a new stunt. I know I must stay calm before I jump. If I fully commit, I will be fine.”

Television presenter Helen Skelton has taken on many dangerous challenges for charity, such as running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon River in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, which is a long, thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net; she only had a belt around her waist connected to another wire above her. To help her balance and avoid falling, she used a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. 

Helen trained with an expert high-wire walker. Even though she had some circus skills, she found that high-wire walking was very different. “The training was a shock,” Helen said. “I didn’t realize how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, followed by an hour of exercises, and then another hour practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so I could keep going if I slipped. Every time I fell, it hurt a lot. But I had to stay positive: if I got nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!”

On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen calmed herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took her 15 minutes. “That was the scariest thing I’ve done,” she said afterward. “I’m glad it’s over!” Despite this experience, Helen is already planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by skiing, kiting, and biking.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, which is an old-fashioned bicycle with one large wheel and one small wheel. Before this, he had written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. He loved motorsport and worked building racing car engines. To save money, Jeff rode an old bicycle to work and also used it for a holiday in Amsterdam. He said, "That trip opened my eyes," and decided he wanted to see the world by bike. 

Instead of using a regular touring bike, Jeff wanted to build his own. He thought the most interesting bike would be a penny farthing, so he visited a museum to learn how they were made. After two attempts in 2001 and 2003, which ended because of a knee injury, he finally began his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries on four continents. The highlight of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. 

Although he met other cyclists who could ride up mountains, Jeff never regretted using his penny farthing. He noticed that the further he traveled from home, the more surprised people were by his bike. However, he faced a tough moment when he had to drink dirty water from a stream, which made him very sick.
