The first paragraph was a scientific description, and the second was from the object's point of view, titled "Poem." One student wrote about an oxygen mask, saying it may look strange or scary, but it helps people breathe in emergencies. This unusual choice helped the class understand how poetry works in a unique way. 

In school, I found poetry confusing. I thought every poem was a silly puzzle that made it hard to understand feelings. After school, many people pay less attention to poetry. Sometimes, a poem stands out because it is not continuous prose. It challenges you to read it, but often you feel let down by its simplicity or difficulty. Still, you feel good for trying. 

What do we want from poems? We might expect them to express deep feelings, beautiful images, or clever humor. While this is true, we often turn to movies for tears, articles for information, novels for escape, and music for enjoyment. However, one important quality of poetry is its ambiguity, which reflects the uncertainty of everyday life. 

If you look up "poem" in an online encyclopedia, it will lead you to "poetry," defined as a form of literary art that uses the beauty and rhythm of language. This definition is fine, but it does not capture the essence of the word. "Poem" comes from the Greek word "poí?ma," meaning "a thing made," and a poet is someone who makes things. So, what kind of thing is a poem? 

Some poets compare poems to wild animals, which are unpredictable, or to machines, which are precise. However, these comparisons can break down when examined closely. The real value in trying to define a poem lies in the discussion it creates. Whether you see a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this debate can change how you think about both. It encourages us to see ordinary things in new ways. 

We can easily think of poems as mental objects, especially since song lyrics often stick in our minds. The combination of words and melody has a strong impact, similar to schoolyard rhymes like "Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words can never hurt me." But sometimes, words can hurt, just like sticks and stones. 

When you see a poem in a newspaper or magazine, it can have a powerful effect, even though it is just ink on paper like the prose around it. The empty space around the poem could have been used for a longer article or an ad. A poem is created through writing and rewriting, just like an article or story, but it is not usually made to be sold. Publishers promote poetry collections, but few expect them to make money. A poem exists for its own sake, and because of its unique place in a magazine or book, it can still surprise us, even if just for a moment.

I bought my first metal detector shortly after I got married. At that time, £70 was a lot of money, and I could have used it for something practical for our home. However, my wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first outing. Over the years, every brooch and coin I discovered brought me joy because it made me feel connected to the past. But after the gold ring, it took 40 years before I found something that impressed Marion again.

One dull February afternoon, I had a couple of hours free and a place in mind to search. It was raining, so I chose a nearby spot where I knew there were old farming tools. When my detector first beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then it beeped again. I tried to ignore it, but I couldn’t walk away without checking. I dug down about half a meter and lay in the mud when I saw a rounded, golden ball. I had found brass curtain rails before, so I tried not to get my hopes up. But as I cleaned it off, it turned into a thick, beautifully designed loop. I stopped and stared, remembering to breathe. I had seen something like this before—the Great Torc, which is in the British Museum. It’s a famous piece from Iron Age Britain, over 2,000 years old. A torc is a beautiful necklace made of gold and silver, with gold rings at each end, just like the one I found.

I took it to my car and kept looking at it on the passenger seat during the drive home. I rinsed it in my kitchen sink, which was probably the only cleaning it had since ancient times. “Marion!” I shouted, “I have something for you.” As I admired my find, I heard my wife come in and stop. “What is it?” she asked after a moment. I told her it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn’t try it on because we were afraid of damaging it. At bedtime, I hid it in our wardrobe. We had never been robbed, but I felt anxious. So, I got up, unscrewed a floorboard in my office, and hid it there.

The law says that I must report such finds to the authorities within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc as much as I could before giving it up. I even took it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I brought it to the council office in the same bag. The registrar was talking to someone when I placed the torc on his desk. He turned around, stopped talking, and was amazed. The torc was confirmed as authentic and later sold to my local council. It is now in the British Museum in London. The £350,000 from the sale was shared between the owner of the field and me. 

But the torc means more to me than just money. I feel like I have saved it for the nation. People often say, “Now that you’ve found something so amazing, will you stop detecting?” But I still find brooches and coins interesting. Besides, if a fisherman catches a big fish, he doesn’t stop fishing—there’s always a chance of catching an even bigger one tomorrow.

Sleeping is one of my favorite parts of traveling, but I don’t talk about it much because I feel a bit guilty. When my friends share their carefully planned trips, filled with activities like visiting museums and hiking, I just smile and don’t say much. What would they think if they knew that my travel plans often include long naps during afternoon rainstorms and lazy mornings in comfortable beds? Better sleep is one of the nice benefits of traveling. 

When I visited Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how many hours I spent sleeping—more than 12 hours most days. There were many noisy birds nearby, but it didn’t bother me. Away from home and my own bed, surrounded by new smells and sounds, I could sleep deeply and enjoyably. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, sleep comes more easily. 

I believe that sleep is not just a break from traveling; it is part of the travel experience. When we travel, we expose ourselves to new sights, sounds, and cultures. All this new information fills our minds, and when we sleep, we process it. This is why sleep can feel so much more intense while traveling. 

People often worry about jet lag, but I think the challenges I face after long trips are more about adjusting to new cultures than just time differences. For example, on the Caribbean island of Trinidad, people wake up early to avoid the heat, slow down around 10 a.m. when the sun is strong, and then become active again in the cool evening. Even though Trinidad is only one hour ahead of New York, it takes me days to get used to the island's different sleep patterns. When I finally adjust, I feel like I have truly arrived.

I remember one afternoon in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic, when I had a big lunch with new friends in an apartment overlooking the beautiful Caribbean Sea. After eating, we all felt sleepy, and one by one, my friends went to relax on hammocks and sofas. I realized why they had so many pillows around. I took some for myself and joined them. I had heard about the Latin American tradition of the siesta, but that day I really experienced it. I shared not just sleep, but a piece of Dominican life.

Travel sleep has another great quality: I remember it. Being away from my usual routine, I enjoy the new smells, textures, and sounds that fill my mind while I sleep. If the idea of ‘slow travel’—enjoying every moment instead of rushing—is what makes a modern traveler aware, then what is slower than sleep? Maybe I should stop feeling embarrassed about my love for sleep while traveling and tell my ambitious friends that travel sleep is an important part of the experience too.

The woman turned away from the mirror and asked, "What do you think? Please be honest." Mia picked up a medium-sized hat that was soft and had a nice layer of gauze and a silk bow. "I still think this one looks best on you," she said diplomatically. The woman wrinkled her nose and made a face that made her look like a bulldog. "But it’s so boring," she replied. "Every other woman will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This beautiful little hat will help me stand out." She sighed and touched the red and black mini top hat on her head. "Yes, this is the one I want," she decided. 

Mia knew she couldn’t change the woman’s mind. With a smile, she agreed that the woman would indeed stand out at the wedding. Mia then thought about her own daughter, Jen. Today was Jen’s thirtieth birthday, and they were having a family gathering. It had been a while since they had all been together, and Mia was excited to see Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also looking forward to meeting Jen’s friend, Tattie, whom they didn’t know anything about. When Jen called last week to ask if she could bring Tattie, Mia’s husband, Jeff, had quickly reacted. "Tattie? What kind of name is that?" he asked. "It’s short for Tatiana," Mia explained. "I think it’s nice." Jeff replied, "It sounds very pretentious." He didn’t like anything that seemed showy or fancy. He also didn’t understand Mia’s polite way of speaking. He would have told the woman in the shop that she was choosing the wrong hat and might have even said that a dustbin lid would look better on her. "The problem with you, Mia," he often said, "is that you’re too polite." 

An hour later, Mia closed her shop and entered her home, Medlar House, which was just a short walk from her work. Four years ago, when Luke, their youngest child, moved out, Mia decided to turn the unused barn next to their house into a bright space for her business. Jeff was doubtful. "Do you really think people want to buy hats?" he asked. But Mia knew from her friends that many women struggled to find the perfect hat for special occasions, so she was sure there was a demand. She was right. From the first day, after Jen helped her create a website, Mia’s Hats became successful. Women traveled from far away to visit her shop in Little Pelham, where she created a relaxed and welcoming atmosphere. She let customers try on as many hats as they needed to find the right one. She encouraged them to bring their outfits to make sure everything matched. Recently, she also started selling handbags and costume jewelry.

It’s a long journey from London to Atlanta, and now in his new American home, Lawrence Okoye reflects on his incredible sports journey. He feels confident but is also surprised by how far he has come, from competing in the Olympic discus final to possibly starting a new career in American football. Even though he has never played American football before, it looks like he might be chosen for one of the major teams in the USA.

In Atlanta, Lawrence is still figuring out what his new position involves. The idea that a 21-year-old beginner from London could be selected for one of the biggest teams in American sports seems unbelievable. However, Lawrence is known for proving people wrong. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law but decided to focus on training for the discus instead, after previously playing rugby. Within 20 months of starting discus training, he became the fourth-best discus thrower in the world.

Lawrence originally went to Atlanta for warm-weather training for the discus, preparing for the world championships. He says, “Yes,” when asked if he is really considering a big NFL contract. He had thought about American football before, but it was only when he arrived in the USA that he decided to give it a try. After arriving, he learned about the NFL trials in Atlanta. Even though he had never played the game, he felt confident enough to apply for the trials. 

When asked if he was nervous about competing against experienced players, he replied, “No, not at all. I don’t get nervous for many things.” Although he doesn’t talk a lot, he is sure of his abilities. His performance in various tests showed that he was the most impressive player. “I was very happy to hear that,” he said, showing a rare moment of pride.

However, he is also cautious. He has no experience in American football, so how can he make it onto an NFL team? He says, “From what coaches have told me, I have all the qualities needed. It’s just about how hard I work.” When asked if he will be relaxed while waiting to hear if he has been selected, he said, “I will be. There’s no pressure on me. Many people say I will definitely be chosen, but I’m not too worried.”

This calmness might come from his disappointing experience in the Olympic discus final, where he finished last. He seems to have moved on from that moment and is proud that he qualified for the final with a great last throw. “That was an amazing day,” he says. “The final didn’t go as I wanted, but that’s part of sports. I can always return to it.”

After his Olympic disappointment, some people thought he had let that experience affect him. Lawrence does not want to comment on that. The minimum salary for an NFL player is over $400,000 a year, so the financial reasons are clear. Lawrence has switched from rugby to athletics and now to American football. With all his physical talents, wouldn’t it be better to focus on just one sport? He replies, “I understand why someone would say that. I’m trying to achieve something I’ve dreamed about since I was a kid. If it doesn’t work out, I can go back to the discus, the sport I love. Every decision I’ve made has been thought out.”

We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to see that it was already daylight. Looking out of the window, I saw the empty landscape below. The dark shades of brown and green made me feel better because, even though it was mid-September, it still looked like summer in Siberia. There were no signs of people, just mountains, streams, and forests stretching to the horizon. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled at me sleepily. “Good morning, Robert,” he said, saying my name with a slow Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow, flying to the remote areas to sell safety clothing to local mining companies. His English was almost as poor as my Russian, but with a dictionary, I managed to tell him that I was going to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with a one-way ticket because I planned to ride my bicycle back home to England. 

“But, Robert,” he said, “there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle.” I explained that I believed there was a road, even if not many people used it now. “Alone?” he asked, pointing at me. “No, I will be riding with a friend called Al.” “Just one friend?” “Yes, just one,” I nodded. Sergei still looked unsure and pointed outside, saying “Holodna” (cold). I tried to convince him by using hand gestures to show that I had a lot of warm clothes, but I didn’t mention that I was on a tight budget. Most of my clothes and gear were bought at low prices. I wasn’t sure if they would be good enough, especially my big postman’s over-trousers that I bought for £10.

It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. That morning, the hall was full of tired students. Some were taking notes without much energy. The lecturer was speaking on and on. I was thinking about a dilemma: Should I ask him or not? “Well, why not?” I wrote a note: “Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob.” Al, my old school friend, was sitting in front of me. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to read my handwriting, wrote something back, and passed it to me. I held my breath while I read it: “OK.” 

Six years later, I was going to join Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher. Although I didn’t have full control of my classes, the job was often challenging, rarely boring, and fulfilling. Plus, there were long holidays to go on adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I had used these holidays to meet Al. He had caught the adventure bug after our bike ride through Pakistan and decided to cycle around the world instead of teaching. Since our first ride together, Al had taken on bigger challenges. This round-the-world bike trip was his biggest yet. Sometimes he thought the ride would break him. Even though it sounded tough, I envied him. He was having an amazing adventure, facing new challenges every day, proving the doubters wrong. He was doing something that scared him almost every day, and it made him feel alive.

In The Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots compete by flying through tall pylons that are between 15 and 25 meters high. They make sharp turns, barrel rolls, and loops while flying at speeds of up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to experience what it feels like to be part of this race. 

An hour before my flight, I had to sign two forms. The first one confirmed that I was healthy, and the second one stated that I would empty my pockets because small objects can be dangerous during the flight. I learned that I needed to stay oriented and that "the horizon is your best friend." The pilot would tell me where to look. I also had to promise to relax and enjoy the view when flying upside down.

Half an hour before the flight, I received a safety briefing. I was told not to touch anything during the flight. As we were getting ready to take off, I was nervous. I had to keep my legs up, avoid touching the important steering pedals, and not rest my hands on any switches. I decided that I would not relax and enjoy the flight, even though I knew I needed to stay calm and focused to survive the experience.

When we started to accelerate down the runway, I felt anxious. Dario, the pilot, and I were in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the fastest acrobatic planes in the world. The plane took off, and just two seconds later, we made a sharp turn to the right. I felt the air push out of my lungs. I looked at the horizon, tensed my body, and gasped as I sank into my seat. For a moment, I felt like I weighed 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out and made another sharp left turn, diving down. 

We were now just 10 meters off the ground, aiming for a small space between two pylons. We passed them at 400 km per hour, and I felt a rush of excitement, but then we made another sharp turn. I was allowed to fly the plane for two minutes, but my hands were shaking so much that the plane shook too. Dario spoke to me, but I couldn’t hear him. Instead of answering, he did a barrel roll, turning the plane completely upside down. 

“Are you okay?” he asked. “Yes,” I replied. “Have you had enough?” “No,” I lied. Then he did a loop, flying up and over in a full circle. I know many people would find this thrilling, like riding a rollercoaster, but I thought it was too much. At the top of the loop, while we were upside down, I heard a voice saying, “Relax, relax, look up.” I looked up and saw some fields below us.

The flight lasted about 10 minutes, and it felt easy compared to what the pilots experience during races. As soon as we landed, Dario took out some sandwiches and started eating. I didn’t eat for hours, and that night, I kept dreaming about doing loops in the air.

Doug Allan films wild animals in cold places. If you have ever been impressed by videos of polar bears in a nature documentary, it is likely that he filmed them. He says his ideal temperature is -18°C. Allan trained as a marine biologist and commercial diver. Diving was his first love, where he learned how to survive in cold environments. His big opportunity came when a TV crew arrived in Antarctica, where Allan was working, to make a wildlife documentary. "I ended up showing the crew around, and after 48 hours, I realized that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for me: travel, adventure, and underwater work," he explains. Now, he is a top cameraman and has worked on many important TV wildlife series.

"When I started, not many people had been to Antarctica. There were people who focused on coral, elephants, and chimpanzees. I became known as the 'cold man.' It felt like there were so many amazing moments waiting to be filmed." When he began 35 years ago, the camera and communication technology were very basic. "It is much easier to film today. Back then, if you shot something, you had to remember it. Now, with digital technology, you can film a lot and see it right away. You had to think about what shots you needed next and what you missed. You filmed less because film was very expensive. Today, you can have too much footage."

"My experience in cold conditions is valuable. I know how to handle it. I have spent so much time on sea ice that it feels as easy as crossing the street. I do get cold toes, but the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, diseases, or mosquitoes." Allan says that wildlife filming has many successes, but also failures and embarrassing moments. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes, but he could not identify the birds.

Recently, Allan got permission to film for a major TV series in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean. He knew it would not be easy. This area is home to polar bears and is only for the bravest or most foolish. In April, it is usually -32°C, the wind is strong, and carrying cameras through deep snow is very difficult. After walking for five or more hours a day and watching polar bear dens for 23 days, Allan had only seen one mother bear and her cub. However, on day 24, he felt like he was part of the bear world, moving and sensing like a bear. 

"We find a new hole and wait. We shuffle, hop, bend, stretch, and run to stay warm. After five hours of watching, I catch a quick glimpse that I almost miss. But the camera is focused on the hole, and my eye is on the viewfinder. After a few seconds, I see an unmistakable black nose. The nose becomes a muzzle, then a full head, and in less than a minute, she has her front legs out and is resting on the snow. She looks at me but is not scared. Just as I think it can't get better, she slides down the slope, seemingly enjoying herself," he recalls. Then, two cubs appeared at the den entrance. "Clearly, it’s their first view of the world. It’s showtime on the slopes, and we have front-row seats."

Now, Allan wants to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic, talking to the people who live there and see its effects firsthand. He believes he could create an extraordinary documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk alone to the North Pole without getting supplies along the way. This journey involved swimming in extremely cold water, dealing with frostbite, and facing polar bears. Just eight months later, he reached the South Pole too. Now, he is back in the Arctic, getting ready for an even bigger adventure. Explorers like Pen are confident and determined. This time, however, the mission is very important. Pen and two colleagues will go on a three-month, 1,000-kilometre trek to the North Pole to measure the thickness and density of the ice. No one has done this before, and the results will be crucial for scientists. This research will show how global warming is affecting the ice in the polar regions.

Pen was prepared for this kind of work from a young age. His father’s old nanny, who had worked for the famous polar explorer Scott of the Antarctic, helped toughen him up by sending him out into harsh weather with very few clothes. His father also inspired him with a love for adventures in cold places, and Pen developed great physical strength. He is married to Mary, who loves the outdoors too. She helps run his polar guide business and worries more about him when he is at home than when he is on an expedition. Once, she even raced against him in a mountain event, finishing an hour ahead of him. Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. 

Pen admits that it is harder to be away from his family this time. When he last went on an expedition, his children were very young, and he made a mistake when saying goodbye. He told his son to take care of his mother and sister, which put too much pressure on the boy. This time, Pen plans to have little contact with them while he is in the Arctic because he believes that calling them will remind them of how far away he is. In the days before he leaves, he is carefully preparing his equipment. He knows that once he is on the ice, it will be very difficult to fix anything or do anything complicated.

Joining him on this expedition will be Ann Daniels, a leading polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, the expedition photographer. They will have a support team of six people who will fly in supplies. Pen feels that being part of a team can be stressful for him, and he is also worried about his age. He will turn 47 soon and feels he hasn’t trained as much as he should have. He often finds that organizing things takes more time than he expects, which makes him anxious about the challenges ahead.

Pen believes that this mission connects exploration with the search for knowledge, just like explorers in the past. He admits that reaching the North Pole was mainly a personal goal and didn’t help many people outside the adventure community. This time, however, scientists will benefit from the data they collect, and they want to involve as many people as possible in understanding what is happening in the Arctic Ocean. Pen feels that their skills, which might seem unusual, are now very important and useful to society.

Text: 'I took a year off. What was I going to do? Being a successful Olympian is amazing. I had the opportunity to do more writing, TV work, and speak to businesses and schools. Although these activities were great, I didn’t have anything competitive to focus on. I wanted to stay in shape so I could compete for an Olympic spot if I felt inspired again. So, I signed up for marathons and triathlons. That should have been enough, but I kept thinking about Ben Fogle’s invitation: ‘Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?’ I have always enjoyed rowing and the feeling of the boat moving through the water. I started to miss that feeling, but I wasn’t ready to train every day. Still, I wanted some kind of competition. I asked some of my rowing friends if they wanted to join the race, but they weren’t very excited. I knew that if I entered the race, even though it was called an adventure, I would want to win. Would rowing with Ben give me the best chance to win? No. But being an underdog without pressure was appealing. I contacted Ben. He was going to join the race anyway and had managed to gather the large entry fee and deposit for a boat, making the race a real possibility. We discussed the other costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000, which is a lot of money. We thought we had a better chance than most, but it would still take effort to secure it. Besides the race costs, I also had to think about the money I would lose by being away from home. Speaking at business conferences is one of the best ways to earn money as a retired athlete. It feels good that people are interested, but I find it hard to talk about my past achievements without a new goal. Joining the race would mean I wouldn’t just talk about what I did before; I would actually be doing something again: rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one of the biggest lessons was to appreciate the easy life of a full-time athlete. My preparation for the Olympics was tough, and my life was focused on getting in the best shape. Looking back, it was quite simple. Yes, I trained almost every day, but the training program was clear, and I had doctors and dieticians to help. I was worried about how people would see me racing with a TV presenter. I thought it might look like I just wanted to be on TV, and I should have chosen a better partner to win the race. However, my worries faded as we prepared. The Atlantic Rowing Race is about more than just rowing; it’s also about mental strength. Ben had completed the difficult Marathon des Sables, spent time at sea, and lived on a deserted island. But he couldn’t row well. I was surprised by how little he understood about rowing, and he was shocked by my lack of patience. I could have been more understanding, but I felt it was important to tell Ben how much he needed to improve. I should have realized that this was his level when I agreed to race with him.'

Just over a year ago, I left my job in London to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in northern Finland. At 26, I felt restless and dreamed of cold, beautiful landscapes. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They hired me as a husky dog handler for the busy winter season. From December to February, they take tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the snow and ice, for trips that can last from one hour to five days. They started with six dogs, but now they have more than 100. They also took over a second property called the 'wilderness farm,' which is a simple place with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join the team for three months, but I needed to know that the work would be hard and physical. I started packing right away.

On November 6, while flying to Finland, I stared at a page with over 100 pictures of huskies. I was supposed to memorize their names, but I felt distracted and nervous. Instead, I looked out the window and saw winter coming, with rivers freezing over.

On November 7, I took a bus north through dark forests filled with snow-covered trees. We stopped for reindeer crossing the road. I arrived at the farm after dark, and as soon as I walked in, I was given a pair of boots and sent outside into the cold. Anna asked if I wanted to be thrown in at the deep end, and I followed the sound of barking to the dogsheds. There, I saw people running around, getting the excited huskies ready for sledding. I could barely introduce myself because everyone was too busy. I petted one of the quieter dogs, but then someone told me to get in the sled, and I almost fell in. With a command, we took off into the dark, using only a headlamp for light.

By November 15, I was starting to learn how to be a husky guide, but first, I faced some tough questions about my skills. Anna asked if I was useful, and I wasn’t sure. I realized I didn’t have much experience: I had never driven a snowmobile, done woodwork, or used an axe. But when someone asked if I had a driving license, I nodded, feeling relieved. 

I quickly learned the basics of dog-sledding: lean into the corners, use both feet on the brake to stop, and never let go of the handlebar. However, other tasks were challenging, like feeding and watering the dogs in freezing temperatures. Water would freeze quickly, so we had to make a 'soup' of meat in hot water for them. By the end of my first week, I was overwhelmed with instructions, and my muscles ached from pulling heavy sleds and being pulled by excited huskies. But I felt proud. I emailed my friends, saying, "I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw—in the snow!"

On that day, as Radcliffe ran past the finish line, reporters gathered to understand her amazing performance. They noted that her time was fast enough to qualify for the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Curious journalists asked her about a special natural treatment called emu oil, which Olympic gold medalist Cathy Freeman had suggested to help Radcliffe recover from an injury caused by an accident during her training.

Radcliffe said that she didn’t fully realize how big her achievement was at the time. Looking back, she understands it was a significant moment, but she felt it was just what she was meant to do that day. She and her team had decided not to set any limits on their goals, following the motto: no limits.

During the race, Gary Lough, Radcliffe's husband and coach, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio coverage. Gerard Hartmann, her physiotherapist, was also with him. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent worried that she might not be able to keep up her fast pace and could drop out of the race. Hartmann was angry at this concern, but he understood that someone who didn’t know how fit Radcliffe was might think it was risky to start so quickly.

With 800 meters left, Radcliffe started to think about her time. She realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she ran the last part in less than three minutes. After running 41 kilometers at a fast speed, she managed to sprint the final distance in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, "I can run faster than that." She remembered the race director, Dave Bedford, saying he never thought anyone would come close to that time for a long time. Radcliffe thought, "I will come back and do it next year," and she really believed she could.

Unfortunately, that did not happen. After the race, everyone wanted to know how Radcliffe, who had an unusual running style, had beaten the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had worked with Radcliffe for weeks, giving her daily training sessions to help her manage the 250-300 kilometers she ran each week. He said, "I've worked with 63 Olympic medalists, and no one could handle that level of pain like her. She would make me work hard, and I would have to ice my thumbs afterward because I was in so much pain."

Hartmann described traveling 13 hours from his home in Ireland to Radcliffe's training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, "Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting." There was no time for a friendly greeting; Radcliffe was ready for a two-hour training session. "Paula would push you to your limits, and that’s what made her so good." 

Hartmann dedicated so much time to Radcliffe that his other athletes became jealous. When asked if she knew why no one has come close to her record, Radcliffe said, "Not really. I trained very hard, but there are more talented people out there. I thought Mary Keitany, a two-time London marathon winner, would do it." She explained that maybe people are more focused on competing against each other than on improving themselves. 

She added, "That mental attitude of never slowing down, even when you are winning, probably helped me. I never thought, 'I can relax now,' it was always about pushing myself as hard as I could." Radcliffe did not realize it at the time, but that marathon was the peak of her career. She would never run that fast again, but she inspired many women to take up long-distance running.

When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, was released, I was unsure how viewers and critics would react. At that time, there was a lot of talk about a food ‘revolution’ happening in Britain. I believed we had created a series that truly contributed to this change, but I still worried: would people like a cooking show that included not just techniques but also history, memories, and science? I watched the first episode feeling both happy and nervous. I didn’t need to worry. The show became very successful, leading to many other interesting projects, including a book about my experiences at my restaurant. Each project felt like a journey, whether into the past, the mind, or cooking techniques.

I later wrote several books in a series called ‘Perfection’, each one linked to its own TV show. In these books, the journey was often physical, involving travel and planning. The latest book, In Search of Total Perfection, takes you around the world to meet amazing artisans, like a man who creates golden pasta that tastes better than any other. These artisans have spent years chasing their own ideas of perfection. 

Perfection is very personal. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was difficult, and I knew I would disappoint some people by leaving out their favorites. I could imagine them asking, “Where’s steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?” However, after a long meeting with the TV production team, we finally created a list that included something for everyone. This experience confirmed my belief that everyone has their own idea of perfection, shaped by their emotions, memories, and experiences.

Despite the book’s title, I knew I wouldn’t claim that the recipes were the best or final versions. I believed that by using my cooking skills and scientific knowledge, and by talking to food producers, artisans, chefs, and their customers, I could identify what made these dishes special. The dictionary defines ‘perfection’ as being perfect, but it also means improving through constant practice. It’s about trying new ideas and changing them until you create something unique.

The TV series allowed me to explore many foods, people, and places I had never seen in restaurants before. I was excited to discover how food connects to memories, as I started my career in a similar way. Finding the best ingredients took me around the world. I had many adventures, like visiting a canning factory that was processing the wrong type of tomato and going to a dairy farm that was so far from perfect that we had to stop filming there! While perfecting each recipe, I ended up hand-milking a cow and using dry ice to make ice cream, cooking chicken in a hospital machine, and almost burning my house down trying to get my oven hot enough for a real Neapolitan-style pizza.

We were still a long way from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise, swerved off the road into a field, and stopped. John got out and opened the hood. He looked at the engine for a long time with his hands in his pockets, looking serious. “Actually, I have no idea what I’m doing,” he finally said, and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried, “We can’t stay here forever,” she said. The field went on for miles, filled with grass and many flowers like poppies and daisies. “No, we can’t stay here forever,” I agreed, because it was best to support Bea. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John get smaller as he walked away to find someone who could help with the car. Mum lay down on the grass. “Tell us a story,” she said. Bea lay down next to her. “Go on, tell us a story.” So, I told them about how the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking. I shared everything they talked about: breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and an argument over a worm. “That’s silly, no one understands bird language,” Bea said. My eyes felt wet. “I do.” But I didn’t sound very sure. “Liar.” I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered everything? The more I thought about it, the less sure I became. “Mum…?” But she had fallen asleep in the sun. 

John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van down the road to a hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out. The boys didn’t mind; they waved and smiled at her through the back windows. We followed John into a café that was not far from where our van was parked. “It’s a hotel,” John whispered. “It might be a bit expensive.” “We’ll just have some tea,” Mum said, and we sat in the shade. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot. “It’s like syrup in there,” she said. We stayed at the café all day while John looked sadly at the engine. “I guess it’s a miracle it got us this far,” he said as it started to get dark. Mum took out blankets and made a bed for us in the hotel garden. It felt nice to sleep on the ground. “I’ll have to get us towed into Marrakech,” John said from the other side of Mum. 

Half an hour later, we were in a truck watching our van being pulled behind with John driving. At first, Bea didn’t want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she sat in the front with the driver. I kept thinking about how we would get home now that our van had to be towed everywhere. I thought it might be easier if we could take a boat straight to London. Then I must have fallen asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel ballroom, talking to two other pianists who were also at the Prague Classical Music Festival. They were older than her by about ten years. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city named Liesel or Louisa. They spoke good English and discussed the music they were playing and their recent travels. 

“I think I’m doing Tanglewood this summer,” Lucy said, trying to sound impressive. However, she didn’t really want to go to the Tanglewood festival. She often felt overwhelmed by the concerts and competitions that took her around the world, making her miss so much school that she wasn’t officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she worked with tutors from the University of San Francisco. 

Lucy hadn’t even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists her age from around the world. She was one of the lucky few chosen from thousands of applicants. At the celebration, her dad gave her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant to congratulate her, and her little brother Gus dreamed about being at the same festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took her out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. The truth was, Lucy hadn’t applied herself; her mother had filled out the form and sent in a CD. “I didn’t want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in,” her mom had said. Lucy thought her mom just didn’t want her to say no. Back then, she believed that causing trouble was the worst thing to do, so she didn’t think about trying to back out.

The guy from Tokyo leaned in, surprised. “Tanglewood?” he asked. “Yeah.” “How old are you?” “Fifteen.” He looked at Liesel/Louisa, who said, “Wow.” Lucy didn’t mean to brag; it was hard to know when she was sharing her achievements or showing off. “It’s just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they’re trying…” Liesel/Louisa then looked across the room and said she had to go talk to someone. The guy from Tokyo stayed and asked, “Have you ever been to Japan?” He had long, messy hair, like many musicians, to show they were cool. “Once, when I was about eight,” Lucy replied. 

Just then, Lucy's grandfather came over. “Lucy, let me introduce you to someone,” he said, pulling her away. “And don’t get too friendly with the competition.” “They’re not the competition,” Lucy replied. “Everyone is the competition,” he insisted. He took her around the room, making her talk to important people. Lucy smiled and nodded, understanding only part of the conversations.

Later, in the elevator to their suite, her grandfather said, “You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and people are talking about you. They all know who you are.” Lucy liked that. Being recognized felt good, even if some people were jealous or thought she was too young for the attention. Being a concert pianist didn’t earn her respect from her school friends. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn’t know or care that she could play a difficult Rachmaninov piece. But in places like this, Lucy felt she mattered.

"It's not good for you to spend so much time online. You need to get out into the real world," said Dad. It’s hard to argue with him, so I decided to look into what experts say about this topic, and I found it quite interesting. Research shows that most teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends, a strong sense of identity, and are learning important technical skills for the digital world.

Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says that social networking is now a big part of growing up. Teenagers don’t just use media like adults do; they live in it. This isn’t necessarily good or bad – it depends on how you use it. 

How does our social networking compare to what our parents did when they were young? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, says it’s like the modern version of hanging out at a youth club, where parents used to share jokes and gossip. He believes it helps teenagers build their identity away from their parents and learn to handle teenage issues with their friends.

Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson explains that adolescence is a time for figuring out who you are. Social networking can help with this by allowing you to share your interests, like music or sports, and see different perspectives from others. Research shows that active social networkers are not as self-centered as those who don’t use social media. He adds that for shy people, communicating online can be easier than face-to-face, allowing them to practice social skills in a less stressful way.

Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He believes these sites can help quiet individuals with specific interests connect with others who share those interests. For example, if you’re one of the few people in your school who likes a certain type of music, finding an online group can help you feel less alone and even popular in that context.

Pauline White, a digital education expert, shared that young people who find new interests online and join networks of similar individuals are truly making the most of social networks. She thinks social networking is becoming a creative outlet, with teenagers making videos, podcasts, and blogs about their interests. Photo-sharing sites are also changing how creativity is shared, allowing photographers to connect, learn, and exchange images, which can help them in their future jobs.

She points out that every business uses social media to promote itself, and understanding how it works is important. For instance, if you create a product and have 1,000 friends on social networks, they could all be potential customers. Linking these networks can build your customer base.

Matthews agrees that teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they enter the workforce. He highlights that many sites offer opportunities to collaborate with others to create and share content, which is a valuable skill in today’s job market.

When people think of a relaxing family vacation, they might not imagine a long trip across nine western states in the US and a Canadian province. However, my parents were not looking for a quiet holiday when they planned our summer vacation this year. My dad seemed determined to create what he thought was the perfect family bonding experience. He and my mom often said, “Not enough people do this anymore,” while my twin brother and I exchanged worried looks, thinking there might be good reasons for that!

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and a mix of clothes for any weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. Still, I had some ideas to cope. With barely enough space left for us, we began our “Family Great American Road Trip.” Leaving our big home for smaller places for the next five thousand miles made me wonder what we had gotten into.

We drove west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had our share of adventures. We stopped for the night in Oklahoma, under a sky full of stars, after almost being blown off the road by a dust storm. We quickly learned that cattle have the right-of-way on the road!

The next day, we woke up early and continued our journey. The desert changed to mountains, and the days started to blend together, but each adventure was still unique. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and then went to Pagosa Springs, Colorado, where we noticed a strong smell of sulfur. As we climbed to our next stop, we realized that the roads marked for Jeeps were best for Jeep drivers.

Every place we visited showed a mix of old and new. Dealing with construction traffic became normal. We laughed when we saw the big “CLOSED” signs at the Four Corners Monument. On our way to Yellowstone National Park, we saw many wind farms and watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. We experienced “bear jams,” where traffic would stop to let bears cross, and we had a close encounter with one bear and a worried park ranger, which created unforgettable memories.

As we drove, life back home felt far away, and even the old hotel we stayed in, which had no internet or cell phone service, couldn’t dampen our excitement. The hotel was a creaky, rustic building that was 95 years old, but the views were amazing. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, we headed back south. My parents were right; you don’t need to travel to a faraway place to find something special.

Returning home was a mix of happiness and sadness, but at least I didn’t argue with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos from our journey to look through and remember. I knew that the best memories would be the unexpected and spontaneous moments we shared.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, would join him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, would stay in England. Amy was finishing her last year of school and would live under the care of the college Head. It was important for Amy to stay, and she was happy to have the best room at the college, which had its own kitchen and study area. She also enjoyed free Internet and phone access. Jeff and Dahlia would keep an eye on Amy, whether she liked it or not. 

So, Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. She only had vague memories of her grandmother and had never met her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, her parents were not excited about it, but Daisy was happy to have Rose with her. Rose didn’t fully understand why her parents didn’t get along with her grandma, but there had been a disagreement in the past, which meant Rose spent her summers away from Daisy. The last time Rose saw her grandmother, she was only ten years old, but she remembered those times fondly. Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and loved to bring people together. Rose could expect dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips soon, which made her smile. Daisy was not a typical old lady; she seemed to go to more social events than anyone else.

Before the move, Dahlia and Rose had a serious talk. Rose was sensible and mature for her age. She knew about healthy eating, staying fit, and getting enough sleep. But this time, Rose wanted one thing: her independence. Living with Daisy would meet her needs, but Rose wanted to play music loudly, invite friends over, and go out without asking for permission every time. She felt she could be trusted to do these things. She didn’t want to be reminded about homework or staying out late, and she didn’t want to be taken everywhere by her grandmother. Daisy understood.

Dahlia gave Rose a new touch-screen mobile phone with a video camera for emergencies only, which made Rose very happy. They all agreed that it would be about trust. Daisy would trust Rose to make good decisions, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too controlling. If either of them crossed a line, they would talk about it again. Rose was not a wild child. Her few school friends were similar, so her school reports were always good, and her exam results were excellent. 

In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and begin her life again. This would be her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced. At least she knew this would be the last time, as she would be starting her final two years of school. For Rose, it was a new beginning, a new piece in the puzzle of her life.

Charlotte Grainger shares that her primary school teacher was the first person to think she might write a novel. She felt that writing a book was a big challenge and thought it would be a great achievement. When she turned 13, she decided to try writing a novel. Now, that novel is about to be published. When she told her former teacher about it, her teacher was surprised. The teacher had thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40, but Charlotte didn’t understand why she should wait to do something she was good at.

It was a winter afternoon when I met Charlotte in her publisher's office. I knew I was going to interview a 15-year-old girl about her book, but I was still surprised to see a teenager there. The book is a significant achievement; it is exciting and well-written. The only thing that shows it was written by a teenager is the age of the main character. A public relations representative was with us in case Charlotte needed help, but she didn’t. Charlotte is confident, smart, and steady, which keeps her from being overly confident.

Charlotte understands that she is still young. When I asked her about the complex moral questions in her book, she said, “I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don’t have many life lessons to share with my readers.” She believes that her age does not limit her understanding of the world, but she also doesn’t think she is very wise. She was interested in the theme of taking responsibility.

Charlotte has a theory about how teenagers are often misrepresented in books. She believes there are three types of teenagers in novels: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the awkward teenager who struggles socially. She found it frustrating to read about these character types. “What if you’re basically fine? There aren’t many stories about characters who are not inadequate in some way. Some writers unintentionally suggest that teenagers can’t know who they are because they lack experience, which can hurt their self-confidence.”

Charlotte has always loved reading famous fantasy authors, but their books almost discouraged her from writing. “They explore deep topics about psychology and life. I wondered if I needed to write like that to create a good book and if I was capable of it.” However, she found a helpful book called How Not to Write a Novel, which taught her that if readers can guess what will happen next, the suspense is likely gone.

Some might say that having parents who are journalists helped her get her novel published. Her father knew someone in publishing, which helped her get her book read. Charlotte recognizes her good luck because it is hard for any new writer to get someone to read their first novel. “Every aspiring writer needs support and a bit of luck, but after that, you are on your own. Ultimately, writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don’t take anything for granted,” Charlotte concludes.

"‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then David, who had some experience with freestyle ski-jumping, stepped forward and skied down the slope towards the jump. He went up the ramp quickly and flew into the air, but something seemed wrong. We held our breath. He landed hard, lost both skis, and flipped into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth said kindly, ‘speed can be unpredictable.’ 

I started to think that maybe freestyle skiing wasn’t for me. On past skiing holidays, I had enjoyed practicing turns in the snow, but I wasn’t like those teenagers who did tricks on ramps and half pipes. I thought it looked fun, but I was afraid of looking silly if I tried to join them. Then my parents decided we would have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. The center had a big indoor area with trampolines and ski jumps covered in artificial snow. Students practiced their tricks and landed in foam pits, which didn’t really prepare us for the real slopes.

After practicing indoors, we went outside to try our skills. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the center’s slogan said. Gareth explained that before places like this, inexperienced ski jumpers would just go down the slopes without any training. He warned us, ‘If you land on the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat area behind the jump before the slope goes down to the landing zone. If you land in the zone, you keep moving forward, which is safer. If you land on the flat, you stop suddenly, which hurts. That’s why speed is important.

At first, I found it hard to ignore my fear and go fast towards the jump. My legs seemed to slow down as I got closer, and I often landed on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday, I felt exhausted. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ Gareth advised. 

On the second day, we started on the trampolines again. I thought I would dislike being indoors while looking at the snowy mountains, but bouncing on the trampolines was fun. Some exercises mimicked the moves we would make while ski-jumping, while others helped us learn ‘aerial awareness’ – understanding what our bodies were doing while in the air. Gareth gave us tips, and I realized I needed to improve my aerial awareness. I was only aware of the moment before take-off and then suddenly found myself in the foam cubes.

We returned to the mountain to try again. There were more mistakes, but eventually, I landed properly. Gareth was as happy as I was, and for a moment, I felt proud of my achievement. But that feeling didn’t last long. On my last run of the day, I forced myself to keep my speed up as I approached the jump. I flew into the air and landed correctly in the landing zone. Then I noticed both of my skis sliding down the slope, no longer attached to my feet."

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty with fear, and you hold tightly to the safety harness. The ride stops suddenly, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly climbs up. Then, there is a quick drop, and your stomach feels like it’s in the air. You move fast, turning sharply left and then upside down. Your senses are overwhelmed, and you scream in fear. But you chose to be there, just like millions of others who pay to enter theme parks.

It is interesting to think about how amusement parks, with their thrilling rides, have become a big business. To create the excitement that visitors want, there are many teams of creative engineers and designers working behind the scenes. The job of a rollercoaster designer might sound like something a child would dream of, but it is actually very challenging. Designers must find the right mix of fun and fear while keeping riders safe. They also need to come up with new ideas to keep people coming back.

While many people believe that rollercoasters are getting more intense, most of the techniques used today were actually developed by a US designer named John Miller in the early 1900s. During that time, there were fewer safety rules, and some rides were quite extreme, which made some passengers uncomfortable. Now, designers have to work within the limits set by specialized ride manufacturers.

I spoke to three experts about rollercoasters. Professor Brendan Walker, a “thrill engineer,” explained that the skill lies in putting all the parts together. Dr. John Roberts, a member of the Royal Academy of Engineering, added that it is important to quickly switch between feelings of excitement and safety so that riders feel thrilled but not scared. 

To create an amazing ride, the teams must develop a strong story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, that matches the ride’s features, such as height, twists, and drops. However, Professor Walker noted that, like in many creative fields, experience and intuition are key. Jeff Hornick, a senior director in theme park development, agreed that it helps to be passionate about thrills to understand what riders want and to test the rides before they open.

I asked the experts if rollercoaster designers would use new technologies like virtual reality. Walker said we shouldn’t expect too much from it. He explained that while virtual reality can enhance the experience, the real excitement comes from the physical ride itself, which will continue to be the main attraction for many years.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already done a lot as a choreographer, creating performances for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances occasionally. I wonder why she manages to do both activities in her busy life. She explains, “Dancing again reminds me of what it’s like to be in the studio, following the orders of strict choreographers, which can be tense and frustrating. Choreographers sometimes forget how hard it is to rehearse all day.”

As a choreographer, Miranda teaches and enjoys working with young dancers. She says, “Beginners are often open to new ideas. Working with them can be easier than with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They want to succeed but don’t yet know their strengths and weaknesses. This makes them more open to criticism, although they might still question me sometimes, and I appreciate their honest feedback.”

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, following the music. “There might be music I don’t like, but I still create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a certain piece, it can be frustrating, but I have to find solutions. I can’t just choose a new piece of music. I wish I could experiment more and switch to different pieces to improve the mood during tough rehearsals. Unfortunately, I often work on big productions where the music is already decided and cannot be changed.”

Miranda believes in making connections with new people. “It’s important to meet new contacts, but I have to remember that each theatre and school has different methods and styles. I need to adapt my way of working each time I go somewhere new, which helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways.”

We discuss a recent documentary about professional ballet dancers and choreographers. Miranda says, “There have been glamorous documentaries in the past that were misleading. This one tries to show the real life inside a dance company. There’s a scene where a young dancer receives many corrections, and I smiled because I recognized that struggle. She knows she’s not getting it right but can’t make her body do what’s needed. It’s hard to watch, but it’s real. People often underestimate the hard work and dedication required in ballet.”

I ask Miranda what makes a great dance production. She replies, “It’s when everything comes together – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers. Perfection might be too much to expect, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences and can help cover up some mistakes. I’ve been part of productions where the dance steps were great, but the costumes or props were distracting, which is disappointing.”

With her wide range of work, I wonder how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? She says, “People want to label you, and I don’t understand that. There’s a trend to focus on becoming an expert in a narrow area, but I don’t follow that. Maybe one day I’ll be known for one thing, but for now, I want to explore more.”

A friend once asked me why I travel when I can see everything on television. I agreed that there are amazing things on TV, but I think it’s better to go out and experience the world. This conversation inspired me to take a fun four-day trip and make a film to encourage people to turn off their TVs. 

A friend was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the main part of my film. I added three wheels and some cables to it and attached old seatbelts to carry it. I put my luggage on the sofa and even slept on it at night, including one night on the beach. Some friends joined me, helping to pull the sofa and motivating me to keep going. 

I have done many walking trips in recent years, but this was very different. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and I walked on main roads. This allowed me to stop at roadside cafés and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of sitting on a rock with my sandwiches blowing away in the wind. 

I often had to tell people, “No, I’m not doing this for charity, and I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks about my weekend, I prefer to share how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England rather than talk about the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website.

When I read about guided swimming trips around some small Greek islands, I felt excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I usually travel with, was busy, so I thought a group holiday would be a good idea. The man at the Greek port looked surprised when I asked for a single ferry ticket because the islands are popular with families. I explained that I wouldn’t be alone for long; I would be joining ten others to swim around the small islands. Although he still looked confused, he smiled and let me on the boat.

Before we started, our group had exchanged emails, but there was not much time to talk before our first swim. Our guides told us that a support boat would follow us the whole time and showed us how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, and then it was time for our first real swim of 1.5 km. I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool and swum in rivers, but I had never swum long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves became bigger, and I found myself at the back of the slow group, which was not where I wanted to be. I watched the faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. However, I wanted to finish this first distance, and I was very happy when I finally did it on my own.

The next days followed a routine: jumping in, finding a comfortable speed, and stopping to enjoy the beautiful views. As the swims got longer, I also got faster and enjoyed them more. I felt like I didn’t need the support boat anymore. I can’t wait to come back again next year.

Being a flight attendant is not easy, but it has many rewards. Since I started this job, I have traveled to many places, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, have plenty of time off, and my life is always interesting, which makes it a great job for someone young like me!

As a child, I went to a boarding school far from my family, so I often flew alone when school started and ended. Sometimes I felt lonely, so I asked the flight attendants if I could help serve meals to passengers, and some of them let me. This experience stayed with me when I wanted to leave my banking job and find a new path.

At the interview for the flight attendant position, there were many young people, and many of us were hired. Most of us had good qualifications and were changing careers. Before the interview, I practiced what to say. I didn’t just say I loved to travel, like everyone else. Instead, I talked about my skills and past work experience, and that helped me get the job!

I would recommend this job to anyone because there are many benefits, but the free flights are not the best part. Most airline staff work very hard, and there is a saying: “no one’s finished until everyone’s finished.” It feels like a big family. Even if we don’t see each other all the time, we are still close.

When I’m not working, I don’t have to take my job home with me. If I do have to deal with difficult passengers, which doesn’t happen often, I know the flight will end soon, and I probably won’t see them again!

At the summer camp where I work, I really enjoy watching the children succeed at things they never thought they could do. Most of the children already know how to swim and play table tennis before they arrive, but rock climbing is a new experience for many of them. Some kids feel very nervous at first, but after some encouragement, they agree to try, and in the end, they all reach the top. This makes them feel great.

At the beginning of the week, some children miss their homes. It is not the youngest ones who feel this way the most; it is usually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We do not allow them to use their mobile phones all the time. First, we tell them they can call home after lunch. When they ask again, usually after dinner, we say it is too late to call and suggest they do it tomorrow. Most children feel better after a couple of days, and by the end of the week, they all come to thank us because they have had a wonderful time.

Sometimes, it is not just the children who feel lonely. We also have parents who call frequently to ask how their child is doing, which is often unnecessary. Their son or daughter might be busy playing games or doing other activities, so we have to tell the parents to call back later.

We often see a certain type of child who comes to camp, usually dressed in expensive new clothes. These children often argue when we ask them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand why it is important.

'Rock the Planet' is a musical show where the actors also need to be good musicians. It opened in London last year after being very successful in the USA for five years, where it won the title of 'Best Musical' four times! However, putting on the show with an all-British cast was not easy. In the UK, there are more rules about how many performances young actors can do each week compared to the USA, where they can perform more often. Because of this, they needed twice as many actors in London. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors in the UK, and they have just won their first 'Best Musical' award.

The theatre in London is larger than the one in the USA, and it has been full every night, with many people wanting to hear the songs that became popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, "It’s amazing that I get paid to play, especially with a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar." He shared how busy the young actors are, saying, "We have regular school lessons at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends."

I asked Jamie what his classmates thought of the show. He replied, "My whole class came! The theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, which made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them." When I mentioned that I also play guitar, Jamie found a spare one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called 'Days,' which I didn’t know before. Jamie helped me learn it, and I felt proud when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s skills and wished I could play like him. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes!

Although the young actors were already musicians, some playing several instruments, none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie said the hardest part was looking natural when they first performed together because they were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is definitely worth seeing.
